717895f-a.text:
The Crystal Palace, Sixth Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 40th Streets. The idea of an industrial exposition housed in a building of glass and iron originated in London with the Crystal Palace of 1851, in Hyde Park. The New York building, however, was smaller than its London predecessor, and entirely different in appearance. It was originally planned to build the Crystal Palace in Madison Square Park, but the protests of residents in that fashionable neighborhood compelled the abandonment of the scheme. The land in back of the Croton Reservoir, now Bryant Park, but then known as Reservoir Square, was leased from the City for a nominal rental of one dollar a year. Construction work began in 1852, and the building, housing the first World's Fair to be held in the United States, was formally opened on July 14, 1853, by President Franklin Pierce. The building, however, was not a financial success, as its London predecessor had been. The city took possession in May of 1858, and on October 5 of that year, while the City Fathers were debating the question of the removal of the building, and while the annual exposition of the American Institute was in progress, fire broke out, and the building was completely destroyed. The land was then converted by the city into the present Bryant Park.
This is a photograph made for the sake of preservation from the original, a rare and baldly faded photograph, whose plate has long ago been lost. The original is on deposit in the Library.

713005f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, east from Sixth Ave., and showing prominently Bryant Park, which is on the south side of the aforementioned street. The New York Public Library is at the eastern end of this park and it faces onto the west side of Fifth Ave., between 40th and 42nd Streets. Shown under construction is the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street. Adjoining same is the Salmon Tower, with the Morris Building (formerly Aeolian Hall) and Stern's Dept. Store westward. Across the Library Building is silhouetted the mid-town 42nd Street skyscraper district, with its Chrysler, Lincoln, Chanin, Lefcourt and Colonial and 10 East 40th Street Buildings. This picture donated to the New York Public Library,by Mr. Hoffman on March 27th 1937.

June 1930.

Copywrited by
William Frange

717913f-b.text:
Bryant Park and New York Public Library, looking east from the Bush Terminal Building west of Sixth Avenue, showing the skyscrapers of the Grand Central region. The four tall ones, from left to right, are: the Chrysler Building on the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue and 42nd Street, the Lincoln Building (almost completely hiding the Chanin Building) at 60 East 42nd Street, the Lefcourt Colonial Building at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 41st Street, and 10 East 40th Street at the right. At the time of this picture the New York Trust Building, on the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue
and 40th Street, has not yet been erected.
July 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but also including 500 Fifth Avenue, the skyscraper under construction at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue and
42nd Street.
July 30, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same.
August 19, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

709482f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing portions of the "El" station at that point, prior to demolition. This, by personal observation on the part of the writer,

The photographer is on the southbound platform and he is viewing across the tracks towards the opposite one. The stairway details are of his vantage point. The buildings here shown are at the N. W. corner.
March, 1939
Views 1-2
Wm. Herries

709489f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing final aspects of the Sixth Avenue "El" prior to demolition. The photographer, in both of these views, is standing on the downtown platform
and is viewing northeastward.

No. 1 shows the fore-end of a downtown train and a news-reel photographer making the last journey. No. 2 shows a work train accumulating the wood benches that were a familiar furnishing of every station. The buildings in the background, line the east side of Sixth Avenue, north from 42nd Street. Note
the Hippodrome in the 43rd-44th Street block.
March, 1939

Views: 1-2

Wm. Herries

Sixth Avenue, at West 42nd Street, showing final aspects of the Sixth Avenue "El" prior to demolition. The photographer, in both of these views, is standing on the downtown platform

demolished. (Slide #230)

The photographer is on 42nd Street and is viewing eastward across the Avenue. Bryant Park and the New York Public Library appear in the center under the "El" structure.

No. 2 is a less inclusive view; photographed from a point closer to
the corner (N.W).

March, 1939
Views 1-2

Wm. Herries

709492f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West
42nd Street, and showing this thoroughfare subsequent to the demolition of the elevated line identified with same. Shortly to follow will be the old Hippodrome building. This cleared site from 43rd to 44th
Streets will be used as an auto parking lot. Stern's Department Store at the right and in the background are Rockefeller Center buildings. Subway construction is progressing
at this date.

Views 1, 2: May 6, 1939
View 3: September 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Bryant Park and the New York Public Library (rear) the morning after a snowstorm. This photograph is taken from the 15th floor of the Wurlitzer Building at 116-22 West 42nd Street. On the left is 42nd Street and on the right 40th Street. Sixth Avenue is in the foreground and does not appear while Fifth Avenue is just beyond the Library.

February 16, 1940

Nathan Schwartz
New York Tublic Library
Photostat Division

42nd Street, west from and including Sixth Avenue, showing the new Bush Terminal Building on the south side of the street. About 1923.
Ewing Galloway.

717918f-b.text:
(1)
Demolition of the Federal Hall replica, Bryant Park, east-center; the view is northeast, the year after the George Washington
Bicentennial Celebration.
April 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a later stage.
May 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The center part of the Park, seen from Sixth Avenue, showing the remodelling of the Park in process under the regime of Commissioner Robert Moses, New York's first city-wide Commissioner of Parks. Prior to an enabling act passed in 1934 by the State Legislature, there was a separate Park Commissioner for
each borough.
August 20, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

709491f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 42nd Street,
showing the distinctive Hippodrome between 43rd and 44th Streets. The photographer's vantage point is the Wurlitzer Building,from which he is viewing northeastward. Note the
Sixth Avenue Elevated.
View 2 is from the 42nd Street station of
same while No. 3 is from the street level. In these views, one observes constructional details of the
towering Rockefeller Center.
View 1: August 19, 1930
View 2: June 8, 1932
View 3: May 1, 1933
P. L. Srerr

717930f-a.text:
(1)
Bryant Park, center and south side, seen from Sixth Avenue and
42nd Street, the roof of the Elks' Club.
May 27, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; the Federal Hall replica seen through a g2p in the trees planted along Sixth avenue. This photograph was made the month following the Washington Bicentennial Pageant. "Federal Hall" was kept open all year as a public exhibit.
May 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, a closer and an unobstructed view, showing the Federal Hall replica. This is a copy of the old New York City Hall which stood on Wall Street at Nassau, and which became the property of the Federal government when New York became the temporary capital of the country, in 1789. President Washington was inaugurated on its balcony; and that scene was reenacted here in 1932.
May 1S, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

730135f-a.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.
730135f-a.text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, West 40's and 50's: View 1 is northwestward across the area lying between Sixth Avenue and Broadway and between 42nd and 49th Street. In the lower left corner is the roof of the Hippodrome and the Sixth Avenue "El". The Hotel Astor is on the upper left hand corner. View 2 is northwestward across the West 50's seen from Radio City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential
hotels on Central Park South.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: June 24, 1931
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: December 1, 1932
730135f-a.folder: 6th Avenue and Broadway and 42nd Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
